headline: Pompliano‚Äôs ProCap SPAC Aims for $1B Bitcoin Treasury Splash
summary: Crypto investor and podcast host Anthony Pompliano is taking the MicroStrategy playbook to Wall Street's next level, raising $750 million to go public with his Bitcoin-native financial platform ProCap via a SPAC merger with Columbus Circle Capital Corp. The deal, which was announced Monday, will see ProCap Financial go public on Nasdaq with a plan to rapidly buy and hold up to $1 billion of Bitcoin‚Äîabout an eighth of Michael Saylor's legendary hoard‚Äîmaking it among the biggest BTC treasuries to list on public markets in history. Deal Structure: How ProCap Is Going Public ProCap's route to the public markets is a conventional SPAC play with a cryptocurrency twist. The $750 million financing consists of $516.5 million in equity and $235 million of convertible notes, with U.S. Bank as collateral agent and trustee. Unusually, ProCap is investing $516.5 million to buy Bitcoin within 15 days of signing, giving investors immediate BTC exposure even before the closing of the merger. The convertible notes are 130% convertible and 2x collateralized in cash or Bitcoin, giving institutional backers downside protection. Upon merging, ProCap Financial will be led by Pompliano, offering not just a humongous Bitcoin reserve but also a series of BTC-denominated financial products‚Äîlending, trading, and capital markets‚Äîto generate yield and profits off its balance sheet. Why SPACs Are Back‚ÄîAnd Why Crypto Loves Them SPACs, or Special Purpose Acquisition Companies, are making a comeback in 2025 after a two-year absence, with the help of a better regulatory climate and a slowdown in traditional IPOs. SPACs offer crypto firms a short-cut to the public markets, sidestepping the lengthy and costly IPO route. ProCap's transaction is the largest initial raise for a publicly listed Bitcoin treasury business thus far, demonstrating Wall Street's appetites for risk and digital assets once more. The property is also a testament to the growing ‚ÄùBitcoin treasury‚Äù trend, spearheaded by MicroStrategy (now Strategy) and holding over 592,000 BTC. ProCap's $1 billion target would represent about 12.5% of Saylor's stack and be among the largest corporate BTC holders globally. Regulatory Hurdles and Listing-Day Pricing Even with the hype, the deal is under quite high regulatory scrutiny. The transaction is expected to be finalized in 2025, pending shareholder approval and SEC approval. According to experts, although the SPAC framework allows for speed, it also brings scrutiny‚Äîespecially for crypto firms that are grappling with evolving custody, accounting, and reporting requirements. ProCap's hiring of U.S. Bank as collateral agent and its spot BTC buying initiative are meant to appease regulators and investors both. Valuation will be done on the final closing price of BTC bought, but with Bitcoin above $100,000, the market capitalization of ProCap can equal or even surpass some traditional financial institutions. Listing will come with the ticker $CCCM and provides shareholders with near-immediate exposure to BTC. SPACs, Bitcoin Treasuries, and Wall Street's Crypto Pivot ProCap's flashy entrance is symptomatic of a broader phenomenon: public companies vying to be ‚ÄùBitcoin proxies‚Äù for investors who would like exposure to digital currencies without the hassle of wallets or exchanges. More than 70 public companies collectively now hold over $67 billion in BTC, and 30+ new crypto treasury transactions have been announced since April. The SPAC route is specially attractive with Wall Street banks and institutional investors becoming friendly to the space and the Trump administration's light regulatory touch inviting new listings. While the SPAC renaissance and ProCap's aggressive listing have sparked the market, some experts warn against forces of a bubble and savvy risk management. ‚ÄùThere's an old George Soros quote: When I see a bubble, I buy,‚Äù Pompliano joked, ‚Äùbecause the trend works.‚Äù However, ProCap's successful listing will be contingent upon regulatory openness, timing in the markets, and learning how to generate yield from its BTC stack‚Äîsomething even Saylor's Strategy now attempts to accomplish. Bottom Line Pompliano's ProCap SPAC is a landmark for Bitcoin public market adoption and the return of SPACs to Wall Street's main stage. With $750 million in capital and a $1 billion BTC target, ProCap stands poised to raise the bar for corporate crypto treasuries‚Äîif it can clear the regulatory hurdle and fulfill its bold vision.

headline: Federal Reserve‚Äôs Pivotal Shift: Ending ‚ÄòReputational Risk‚Äô in Bank Supervision
summary: BitcoinWorld Federal Reserve‚Äôs Pivotal Shift: Ending ‚ÄòReputational Risk‚Äô in Bank Supervision The cryptocurrency world is buzzing with a significant development that could reshape how digital asset firms interact with traditional banking. The Federal Reserve, the central bank of the United States, has just made a pivotal announcement: it will no longer consider ‚Äúreputational risk‚Äù as a standalone factor in its bank supervision guidelines. This move, initially brought to light by Eleanor Terrett on X, signals a profound shift, particularly for crypto firms that have long struggled with banking access. Understanding the Shift in Federal Reserve Guidelines For years, the term ‚Äúreputational risk‚Äù has been a contentious point in the banking sector, especially concerning businesses deemed ‚Äúhigh-risk‚Äù or ‚Äúnovel‚Äù ‚Äì a category into which many cryptocurrency companies often fell. This vague classification allowed banks to deny services to crypto firms, citing potential damage to their public image, even if the firms themselves were operating legally and compliantly. This often led to the frustrating phenomenon known as ‚Äúdebanking.‚Äù The Federal Reserve‚Äôs decision means this subjective criterion is being removed from their official bank examination manuals. Instead, examiners will now be retrained to focus solely on concrete financial risks, such as money laundering, fraud, and terrorism financing ‚Äì risks that are quantifiable and can be mitigated through established compliance protocols. This change represents a crucial step towards creating a more objective and fair banking environment for all legitimate businesses, including those in the digital asset space. The Impact of Ending Reputational Risk for Crypto Firms The removal of ‚Äúreputational risk‚Äù from the Fed‚Äôs lexicon is a monumental victory for the crypto industry. Historically, many legitimate crypto businesses, from exchanges to blockchain developers, found themselves shut out of traditional banking services. This wasn‚Äôt necessarily due to actual financial misconduct but rather a perception of risk or a lack of understanding from financial institutions. Increased Banking Access: This change could open doors for crypto firms that previously struggled to secure bank accounts, loans, and other essential financial services. Banks might now be more willing to engage with crypto businesses without the looming threat of regulatory scrutiny based on subjective reputational concerns. Reduced Debanking: The practice of ‚Äúdebanking,‚Äù where banks unilaterally terminate relationships with crypto companies, is expected to decrease. This provides much-needed stability and predictability for an industry that thrives on innovation but has been hampered by banking instability. Level Playing Field: By focusing on tangible financial risks, the Fed is helping to create a more level playing field. Crypto firms, like any other business, will now be evaluated based on their adherence to anti-money laundering (AML) and know-your-customer (KYC) regulations, rather than on their perceived ‚Äúnewness‚Äù or ‚Äúriskiness‚Äù by association. This isn‚Äôt just about convenience; it‚Äôs about legitimizing an entire sector. When crypto firms can access banking services, they can operate more efficiently, grow, and contribute more effectively to the broader economy. It‚Äôs a clear signal that regulators are moving towards integrating digital assets into the mainstream financial system, albeit cautiously. How Bank Supervision is Evolving The Federal Reserve is not acting in isolation. It is the last major U.S. financial regulator to make this specific change, following in the footsteps of others like the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC). This concerted effort across multiple regulatory bodies suggests a unified approach to modernizing bank supervision and fostering innovation responsibly. The evolution of bank supervision can be seen in several key shifts: From Subjective to Objective: Moving away from vague ‚Äúreputational‚Äù concerns towards measurable financial risks. Focus on Risk Management: Emphasizing robust internal controls, compliance programs, and due diligence processes within banks. Technological Adaptation: Regulators are increasingly understanding the nuances of blockchain technology and digital assets, leading to more informed policy decisions. This evolving landscape requires banks to adapt their internal frameworks. Instead of simply avoiding crypto, they must now develop sophisticated risk assessment models that can accurately evaluate the financial crime risks associated with digital asset transactions. This encourages banks to become more knowledgeable about the crypto space, which can only benefit the ecosystem in the long run. Addressing Crypto Debanking : A Historical Perspective The issue of crypto debanking has been a persistent thorn in the side of the digital asset industry for years. Many crypto businesses, even those with strong compliance frameworks, found themselves without banking partners. This was often driven by a combination of factors: Regulatory Uncertainty: A lack of clear guidelines from regulators made banks hesitant to engage with crypto. Perceived High Risk: The nascent nature of the industry and its association with illicit activities (even if a small percentage) led to a blanket classification of ‚Äúhigh risk.‚Äù Operational Burden: Banks found it complex and costly to implement the necessary AML/KYC procedures for crypto businesses, often opting to avoid them entirely. ‚ÄúReputational Risk‚Äù Concerns: The fear that associating with crypto could damage their standing with customers or regulators was a significant deterrent. The Federal Reserve‚Äôs latest move directly addresses the fourth point, removing a major hurdle. This historical context underscores the significance of the Fed‚Äôs decision. It‚Äôs not just a minor policy tweak; it‚Äôs a direct response to years of advocacy from the crypto industry and a recognition of the need for a more balanced regulatory approach. What Does This Mean for US Financial Regulators and the Future? With the Federal Reserve now aligning with other major US financial regulators on this specific issue, there‚Äôs a clearer, more consistent message being sent to the banking industry: don‚Äôt debank legitimate businesses simply because of their industry. Instead, focus on effective risk management. This convergence among regulators bodes well for the future of crypto in the United States. It suggests a growing maturity in regulatory thinking, moving from outright avoidance or extreme caution to a more nuanced approach that seeks to integrate digital assets responsibly into the financial system. Key Takeaways for the Future: Increased Clarity: Banks can expect more consistent guidance from regulators regarding how to engage with crypto firms. Innovation Encouraged: A more stable banking environment could foster greater innovation within the crypto space, as businesses can operate with more confidence. Continued Scrutiny on Financial Risks: While ‚Äúreputational risk‚Äù is out, the focus on robust AML, KYC, and anti-fraud measures will remain paramount. Crypto firms must continue to prioritize compliance. Potential for New Banking Models: This shift might encourage more traditional banks to develop specialized departments or services tailored for crypto businesses. The path forward won‚Äôt be without its challenges. Banks will need to invest in training, technology, and expertise to properly assess and manage the financial risks associated with crypto. However, the regulatory landscape is undeniably shifting towards greater acceptance and integration. Challenges and Opportunities Ahead While the Fed‚Äôs decision is overwhelmingly positive, it‚Äôs important to acknowledge that challenges remain. Banks will still need to overcome their own internal biases and invest in the necessary infrastructure to serve crypto clients compliantly. For crypto firms, the onus remains on demonstrating impeccable compliance and transparency. Opportunities: Growth of Crypto-Friendly Banks: We may see an increase in the number of banks willing to serve crypto businesses, potentially leading to more competitive services. Mainstream Adoption: Easier banking access could accelerate the mainstream adoption of cryptocurrencies and blockchain technology. Regulatory Certainty: This move contributes to a broader trend of increasing regulatory clarity, which is crucial for industry growth. Challenges: Bank Reluctance: Some banks may still be hesitant due to a lack of understanding or existing risk aversion, even without the ‚Äúreputational risk‚Äù clause. Compliance Costs: Implementing robust AML/KYC for crypto remains complex and potentially costly for banks. Evolving Threats: The crypto landscape is dynamic, and new financial crime risks can emerge, requiring continuous adaptation from both banks and regulators. Actionable Insights for Crypto Businesses and Banks For crypto firms, this is a call to double down on compliance. While a major hurdle has been removed, the expectation for robust AML/KYC frameworks remains. Banks, on the other hand, should view this as an opportunity to expand their client base and adapt to the evolving financial landscape. For Crypto Firms: Strengthen Compliance: Ensure your AML, KYC, and anti-fraud programs are top-notch and demonstrable. Educate Banks: Be prepared to educate potential banking partners about your operations and compliance measures. Seek Proactive Engagement: Reach out to banks that are showing signs of openness to the crypto sector. For Banks: Invest in Expertise: Train staff on blockchain technology, cryptocurrencies, and associated financial crime risks. Develop Tailored Solutions: Consider creating specific banking products and services for the digital asset industry. Review Risk Frameworks: Update internal risk assessment models to align with the Fed‚Äôs new guidance, focusing on tangible financial risks. The Federal Reserve‚Äôs decision to remove ‚Äúreputational risk‚Äù from its bank supervision guidelines marks a truly transformative moment for the cryptocurrency industry. It‚Äôs a clear signal that legitimate crypto firms deserve fair access to banking services, judged on concrete financial risks rather than subjective perceptions. This move, aligning the Fed with other major U.S. regulators, paves the way for a more integrated, stable, and innovative financial ecosystem. While challenges remain, the path forward for crypto-traditional finance collaboration looks significantly brighter. This isn‚Äôt just about policy; it‚Äôs about fostering an environment where innovation can truly thrive without unnecessary barriers. headline: Pulte‚Äôs FHFA eyes crypto in $8.5 trillion U.S. housing and mortgage markets ‚Äî what‚Äôs next?
summary: What does Pulte‚Äôs FHFA crypto mortgage signal actually mean for American homebuyers, and could it rewrite lending norms for those who store wealth in Bitcoin and stablecoins? Table of Contents Mortgage, Pulte, and FHFA enter the crypto conversation Freddie Mac compliance drives lender finance models How crypto might be evaluated Gains in private finance suggest real demand for Bitcoin integration Mortgage, Pulte, and FHFA enter the crypto conversation In a recent announcement, Federal Housing Finance Agency Director Bill Pulte has publicly stated that the agency will ‚Äústudy the usage of cryptocurrency holdings as it relates to qualifying for mortgages.‚Äù The announcement, posted on X on Jun. 24, introduces the possibility that Bitcoin ( BTC ) and other digital assets could soon factor into U.S. home loan evaluations. We will study the usage pf cryptocurrency holdings as it relates to qualifying for mortgages. ‚Äî Pulte (@pulte) June 24, 2025 The idea comes at a time when housing access remains strained. As of mid-2025, the average rate for a 30-year fixed mortgage is just under 7%, the highest level since the mid-2000s. 30-year fixed mortgage rate chart | Source: FRED In May, the median price for an existing home reached $422,800, a record high for the month. Existing home sales have also slowed sharply, with May 2025 marking the weakest pace for that month since 2009. Meanwhile, the affordability squeeze is especially pronounced for first-time buyers. According to the National Association of Realtors, only 30% of home purchases are currently being made by first-time buyers, well below the 40% share considered typical for a balanced market. Rising monthly payments and strict lending criteria have made access difficult for younger buyers and self-employed individuals, particularly those with irregular income but sizable assets. The FHFA is now examining whether crypto holdings could be considered similar to savings, investment portfolios, or other assets during mortgage evaluations. Under such a framework, for example, a person holding $200,000 worth of Bitcoin or Ethereum ( ETH ), but lacking a traditional salary, might still qualify for a loan based on their overall net worth. At present, most mortgage lenders exclude crypto from financial assessments, citing concerns over price volatility, limited regulatory clarity, and the challenges of verifying digital asset ownership. Even high net-worth applicants holding substantial crypto assets are often treated as lacking adequate financial stability under current standards. The FHFA‚Äôs announcement does not indicate a finalized policy or regulatory timeline. The review remains in its early stages, and many operational and legal questions will need to be addressed before any change is implemented. Freddie Mac compliance drives lender finance models The FHFA plays a quiet but central role in shaping how Americans access home loans. It oversees Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the two government-sponsored entities that guarantee the majority of mortgage loans in the United States. It also regulates the Federal Home Loan Bank system, a network of regional banks that provide liquidity to housing and community development lenders. According to the agency‚Äôs data, these institutions collectively support over $8.5 trillion in U.S. home financing. Any change in policy issued by the FHFA carries broad market consequences. Updates to guidelines on credit scores, down payments, or eligible asset classes often influence how banks and lenders structure their loan products. Most lending institutions follow FHFA standards to ensure that their mortgages remain eligible for resale to Fannie or Freddie, which helps manage long-term risk exposure. The agency was established in 2008, following the housing market collapse, with a mandate to strengthen oversight and preserve the safety and liquidity of the mortgage finance system. Within that framework, even a preliminary inquiry into counting crypto assets toward mortgage qualifications carries real weight. The agency‚Äôs current direction is closely tied to the background of its director, Bill Pulte. Appointed in March 2025 during President Trump ‚Äôs second term, Pulte took office after a lengthy confirmation process. He is the grandson of William Pulte, founder of Pulte Homes, one of the largest homebuilders in the country. Before entering public service, Pulte led Pulte Capital, a private investment firm. He also gained a public following through philanthropic giveaways on X, where he became known as the ‚ÄúTwitter Philanthropist.‚Äù Unlike his predecessors, Pulte has direct involvement in the crypto space. Financial disclosures show personal holdings of $500,000 to $1 million in Bitcoin, along with a similar-sized position in Solana ( SOL ). He also holds equity in Marathon Digital Holdings, a U.S.-based Bitcoin mining company, and has previously invested in speculative stocks such as GameStop. His profile stands out in a field typically characterized by conservative financial backgrounds. Pulte has publicly supported crypto since 2019, using his social media presence to promote adoption and encourage policy openness toward digital assets. While the FHFA‚Äôs review of crypto in mortgage underwriting is still early and exploratory, its very consideration reflects a shift in both the asset class‚Äôs relevance and the leadership‚Äôs priorities. How crypto might be evaluated Pulte‚Äôs announcement has raised fresh questions about how crypto holdings might eventually be evaluated under mortgage lending standards. Currently, borrowers who want to use digital assets in the mortgage process must first convert them into U.S. dollars and deposit the funds into a regulated American bank account. To meet eligibility for down payments or reserves under Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac guidelines, those funds must also be seasoned, meaning they must remain in the account for at least 60 days. The FHFA‚Äôs review is expected to examine whether these requirements can or should be updated. One likely area of focus is asset valuation. Due to the volatility of crypto assets like Bitcoin and Ethereum, lenders may hesitate to accept their full market value when assessing borrower assets. A common method in traditional finance is to apply a haircut ‚Äî a discount from the stated value ‚Äî to account for potential price swings. Whether similar adjustments would be adopted for crypto remains uncertain. Holding history may also come under review. Lenders often view long-held assets more favorably than short-term holdings. Assets with clear documentation, consistent custody, and minimal trading activity may carry more weight than those recently acquired or frequently moved. Stablecoins present a separate set of considerations. Tokens such as USD Coin ( USDC ) and Tether ( USDT ) are designed to maintain a consistent value relative to the U.S. dollar, which may make them more suitable for underwriting purposes. Even so, treatment of stablecoins would depend on regulatory comfort with their structure, custody arrangements, and transparency standards. For now, mortgage advisors commonly recommend that crypto holders convert their assets to dollars well in advance of applying for a loan, giving lenders time to verify the source of funds and ensuring the assets meet seasoning requirements. Any future update is likely to preserve strict documentation standards. Borrowers would still need to show a complete audit trail, including wallet ownership, transaction history, and evidence that the funds are not tied to loans or suspicious activity. Verification of custody, clarity of origin, and compliance with anti-money laundering rules are also expected to remain central to any policy changes under consideration. Gains in private finance suggest real demand for Bitcoin integration While federal regulators are just beginning to explore the idea of integrating crypto into mortgage lending, several private fintech firms have already launched experimental models. Milo Credit, a Florida-based lender, introduced one of the first crypto mortgage products in the U.S. in 2022. Its structure departs from the traditional approach. Rather than requiring borrowers to sell crypto and make a cash down payment, Milo allows buyers to pledge digital assets, such as Bitcoin, Ethereum, or certain stablecoins, as collateral. The setup enables clients to finance up to 100% of the home‚Äôs value without liquidating their crypto holdings. Similarly, Figure Technologies, a San Francisco fintech company led by former SoFi CEO Mike Cagney, has explored large-scale crypto-backed mortgage programs, offering loans as high as $20 million using digital assets as security. According to Milo, clients continue to retain ownership of their pledged crypto, which means they can benefit if asset values rise during the mortgage term. Another advantage is tax-related: selling large crypto positions to cover a down payment would typically trigger capital gains taxes. By pledging rather than selling, borrowers avoid those immediate tax events. As of early-2025, Milo reported over $65 million in crypto-collateralized home loans issued. However, these private offerings function outside the federal mortgage system. Their loans are not eligible for resale to Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac, meaning they cannot benefit from the same level of liquidity and risk-sharing that conventional loans do. As a result, interest rates tend to be higher, and lenders often retain the loans in-house or work with alternative investors to fund them. These limitations place a ceiling on how widely such products can scale. Another constraint is risk. Crypto-backed mortgages usually require over-collateralization ‚Äî meaning borrowers must pledge more in crypto value than the loan amount to offset volatility. But even with that buffer, price swings can present challenges. A drop of 15% in asset value between approval and closing is enough to disrupt a loan. And historically, crypto drawdowns have been far steeper. If the FHFA chooses to move forward, it could bring more consistency and structure to the space. Private models have shown that crypto can be integrated into housing finance, but only with careful safeguards and a full understanding of its tradeoffs. Whether the outcome is adoption, rejection, or something in between, the process will influence how crypto is viewed not just in capital markets, but in everyday financial life.

headline: Andy Konwinski‚Äôs Visionary $100M Pledge Fuels Independent AI Research Through Laude Institute
summary: BitcoinWorld Andy Konwinski‚Äôs Visionary $100M Pledge Fuels Independent AI Research Through Laude Institute In a truly transformative move poised to reshape the landscape of artificial intelligence, Andy Konwinski , a visionary co-founder behind tech giants Databricks and Perplexity AI , has announced a monumental $100 million pledge for his new venture, Laude Institute . This bold initiative aims to inject fresh capital and independent thought into the burgeoning field of AI research , promising a new era for innovation that prioritizes beneficial outcomes over purely commercial gains. For those invested in the future of technology and its ethical development, Konwinski‚Äôs commitment marks a pivotal moment. Andy Konwinski‚Äôs Vision: Catalyzing Independent AI Research Andy Konwinski , a computer scientist with a formidable track record, has always been at the forefront of technological advancement. His co-founding roles at Databricks , a leader in big data analytics and AI, and Perplexity AI , a revolutionary conversational answer engine, speak volumes about his foresight. On Monday, Konwinski unveiled his personal company, Laude, is forming a new AI research institute, backed by a significant $100 million of his own money. This isn‚Äôt just another lab; the Laude Institute is structured more like a fund, making investments akin to grants, designed to empower researchers without the immediate pressures of commercialization. The institute‚Äôs board boasts an impressive lineup of academic and industry luminaries: Dave Patterson: A UC Berkeley professor renowned for his award-winning research in computer architecture. Jeff Dean: Known globally as Google‚Äôs chief scientist, a titan in AI development. Joelle Pineau: Meta‚Äôs vice president of AI Research, bringing deep expertise from a major tech player. The Laude Institute has already made its first significant commitment: a flagship grant of $3 million per year for five years. This substantial funding will anchor the new AI Systems Lab at UC Berkeley, a lab set to open in 2027 and led by the celebrated Ion Stoica. Stoica, also a co-founder of Anyscale and Databricks, both born from Berkeley‚Äôs lab system, brings invaluable experience to this new endeavor. This foundational grant underscores Laude‚Äôs commitment to fostering deep, impactful AI research at leading academic institutions. The Laude Institute: A New Paradigm for AI Advancement Konwinski articulated the Laude Institute‚Äôs core mission in his blog post, describing it as ‚Äúbuilt by and for computer science researchers ‚Ä¶ We exist to catalyze work that doesn‚Äôt just push the field forward but guides it towards more beneficial outcomes.‚Äù This statement is a subtle yet pointed commentary on the current landscape of AI development, where many organizations, including those that started with noble research goals like OpenAI, have arguably become consumed by their commercial ambitions. The institute‚Äôs structure is unique, operating across boundaries as a nonprofit with a public benefit corporation arm. Konwinski is strategically dividing his research investments into two distinct categories: Slingshots: These are geared towards early-stage research projects that can benefit from grants and hands-on support, providing the initial push for promising ideas. Moonshots: As the name suggests, these are long-horizon labs tackling ‚Äúspecies-level challenges‚Äù such as AI for scientific discovery, civic discourse, healthcare, and workforce reskilling. This bucket aims for truly groundbreaking, long-term impact. For instance, Laude has already collaborated with ‚Äúterminal-bench,‚Äù a Stanford-led benchmark designed to assess how well AI agents handle tasks, a tool actively utilized by companies like Anthropic. This demonstrates a practical approach to fostering foundational tools that benefit the wider AI research community. Beyond Profit: The Imperative for Ethical AI Research The increasing commercialization of AI has led to a muddled research environment. We‚Äôve seen a proliferation of AI benchmarks designed to prove that a particular vendor‚Äôs model works best, rather than objectively measuring progress. Even major players like Salesforce have developed their own LLM benchmarks for CRMs, highlighting a trend where research often serves commercial interests. A recent controversy involving popular AI researcher Epoch, which revealed OpenAI supported the creation of one of its AI benchmarks used to unveil its new o3 model, further illustrates this blurred line. The founder of Epoch also launched a startup with the controversial mission to replace all human workers everywhere with AI agents. These examples underscore the urgent need for truly independent AI research that is not swayed by commercial pressures or profit motives. This is where an alliance like the one Konwinski is forging, with the likes of Jeff Dean and Ion Stoica, becomes critically important. Their support for independent research could lead to innovations that are genuinely ‚Äúhuman-helpful‚Äù and foster a more ethical, beneficial path for AI development. This initiative presents an attractive alternative to the often-conflicted models currently dominating the space. The Financial Backbone: Success of Databricks and Perplexity AI Many might wonder how Andy Konwinski amassed the fortune necessary to pledge a staggering $100 million to this new endeavor. The answer lies in the phenomenal success of his previous ventures, particularly Databricks and Perplexity AI . In January, Databricks closed a funding round that valued the company at an astounding $62 billion, a testament to its pivotal role in the big data and AI landscape. Similarly, Perplexity AI secured a $14 billion valuation just last month, solidifying its position as a major player in conversational AI. It is important to note that Konwinski‚Äôs company, Laude, isn‚Äôt solely a grant-writing research institute. He also co-founded a for-profit venture fund, launched in 2024, with former NEA VC Pete Sonsini. This fund has quietly backed other startups and notably led a $12 million investment in AI agent infrastructure startup Arcade, as previously reported by Bitcoin World. A spokesperson for Laude confirmed that while Konwinski has pledged the initial $100 million, he is also actively seeking and open to additional investment from other successful technologists, signaling a broader vision for the fund‚Äôs impact. Why Laude Matters: Shaping the Future of AI In a world grappling with the rapid advancements of artificial intelligence, a pertinent question arises: does the world truly need yet another AI ‚Äúgood for humanity‚Äù research institute, especially one with a potentially murky nonprofit/commercial structure? The answer is both no, and emphatically yes. While the landscape of AI research has become increasingly muddled with commercial interests, the unique structure and clear mission of the Laude Institute offer a refreshing counter-narrative. By bringing together a formidable alliance of minds like Konwinski, Dean, and Stoica, Laude is poised to champion truly independent research. This independence is crucial for developing unbiased benchmarks, exploring ethical implications, and ensuring that AI innovations ultimately serve humanity rather than just corporate bottom lines. The potential for this initiative to foster genuinely independent, human-centric commerce and innovation is immense. Konwinski‚Äôs substantial pledge and the institute‚Äôs focus on ‚ÄúSlingshots‚Äù and ‚ÄúMoonshots‚Äù could ignite breakthroughs that address species-level challenges, steering the powerful currents of AI towards more beneficial outcomes for society as a whole. It‚Äôs an exciting prospect for anyone hoping for a more responsible and impactful future for AI. headline: US Federal Reserve Drops ‚ÄòReputational Risk‚Äô Requirements for Banks, Ending Era of Crypto Debanking
summary: The US Federal Reserve announced that it will no longer use ‚Äòreputation risk‚Äô to assess banks, ending a practice closely connected to the ‚Äòwar on crypto‚Äô and debanking . Reputation risk was used to pressure US banks to reject crypto startups from receiving banking services such as business loans. The status quo has changed in Washington, giving banks the autonomy to make their risk assessments. The Federal Reserve announced that they were combing through their documentation to replace the term ‚Äòreputation risk‚Äô with more specific examples of ‚Äòfinancial risk‚Äô. The Federal Reserve added that they were still committed to risk assessment and desired banks to follow sound principles. The Fed defined reputational risk as including aspects of negative publicity that hurt a business‚Äôs bottom line or lead to costly litigation procedures. The Fed has now removed the term from its documents and training manuals, focusing on more specific types of risk instead. The Office of the Comptroller and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation both dropped ‚Äòreputational risk‚Äô as an item of assessment. Banks have long disputed the measure as introducing subjective metrics that can be abused by federal organisations and can lead to inaccurate assessments of what could otherwise be legitimate investments. The Fed still expects banks to conduct responsible risk assessment examinations. Banks can still employ ‚Äòreputation risk‚Äô assessments if they believe the methods are valid. Why is Stablecoin Regulation Such a Critical Topic Right Now? Stablecoins, digital currencies designed to maintain a stable value by being pegged to a reserve asset like the U.S. dollar, have emerged as a cornerstone of the cryptocurrency ecosystem. They facilitate trading, enable fast and low-cost international transfers, and are increasingly seen as a bridge between traditional finance and the burgeoning world of decentralized applications. However, their rapid growth and potential for widespread adoption have raised concerns among policymakers. Regulators worry about potential runs similar to bank runs, illicit finance, and the broader implications for financial stability if a major stablecoin were to fail. This makes comprehensive stablecoin regulation not just a matter of convenience, but one of national economic interest. The urgency for clear rules has been amplified by past market volatility and the increasing institutional interest in digital assets. Without a robust regulatory framework, the U.S. risks falling behind other nations that are actively developing their own digital asset policies, potentially ceding its leadership in financial innovation. This touches upon issues of competition, systemic risk, and financial inclusion. headline: Japan‚Äôs FSA proposes adding crypto to its Financial Instruments Act framework
summary: On Tuesday, Japan‚Äôs Financial Services Agency (FSA) proposed a set of rules classifying crypto under the Financial Instruments and Exchange Act as early as 2026. The initiative aims to shift cryptocurrencies from their current classification as a means of settlement under the Payment Services Act. The plan is to be reviewed by the Financial System Council on June 25. The agency aims to legalize Bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and replace the current progressive tax of 55% with a flat 20% on crypto gains. Japan‚Äôs FSA seeks to revise its oversight over crypto service providers The FSA said it intends to implement stricter regulations on companies involved in crypto investments to register with financial authorities. The regulatory change also comes amid a rise in reports of cryptocurrency-related scams. As of April 2025, Japan has been developing its legal and tax regimes for crypto assets. The ruling Liberal Democratic Party‚Äôs Web3 Project Team has proposed the classification of digital assets as a distinct asset under the Financial Instruments and Exchange Act (FIEA). A Financial Services Agency (FSA) survey on investor attitudes found that 7.3% of domestic investors with prior investment experience hold crypto assets, a rate higher than those holding positions in FX trading or corporate bonds. According to the FSA, the proposed changes will align cryptocurrencies with regulations for stocks and other traditional financial instruments. The entity also revealed that it will amend the Financial Instruments and Exchange Act to implement the changes. The amendments to the PSA include the relaxation of reserve requirements for stablecoins. The current regulations require issuers of stablecoins to hold the full issuance value in demand deposits and similar highly liquid instruments. The amendment will permit issuers to manage up to 50% of the issuance value in low-risk assets with minimal risk of principal damage. The other amendment to the PSA will be establishing a new electronic payment crypto asset service system. The existing framework subjects entities acting solely as intermediaries between crypto-asset exchange service providers and users to stringent registration requirements applicable to fully-fledged exchange providers. The amendment will introduce a new category for intermediaries who do not take custody of customer assets. According to the FSA, the intermediaries will focus exclusively on facilitating transactions by connecting users seeking to buy, sell, or exchange crypto assets with registered crypto exchange service providers or electronic payment service providers. The FSA also proposed to allow regulatory authorities to issue an order mandating that a business provider‚Äôs assets be held within Japan. The amendment aims to prevent cross-border outflow of customer assets in the event of insolvency of a crypto exchange or electronic payment service provider dealing only in spot transactions. Japan‚Äôs shift comes amid a larger initiative among regulatory agencies to shift their approach to governing digital assets. In March, the U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission ( CFTC ) said digital asset derivatives will now receive the same regulatory treatment as other products. Regulatory agencies shift their approach to governing crypto In the same period, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. issued new guidance allowing financial institutions under its supervision to engage in crypto-related activities without FDIC approval, as long as they adequately manage the associated risks. ‚ÄúI expect this to be one of several steps the FDIC will take to lay out a new approach for how banks can engage in crypto- and blockchain-related activities in accordance with safety and soundness standards.‚Äù -Travis Hill, Acting Chairman of the FDIC Board of Directors. The agency also expects to issue additional guidance to clarify banks‚Äô engagement in particular crypto-related activities. The FDIC also hopes to collaborate with other banking agencies to provide further guidance or regulations to replace the current interagency documents covering crypto assets. Acting Controller of the Currency Rodney E. Hood mentioned that the OCC expects banks to have the same strong risk management controls to support new bank activities as they do for traditional ones. He believes the initiative will reduce the burden on banks to engage in crypto-related activities and ensure that their activities are treated consistently by the OCC.
